items.title: Pan-basin warming now overshadows robust Pacific Decadal Oscillation
items.body: MainNorth Pacific climate variability has historically been dominated by the Pacific Decadal Oscillation (PDO), an empirical mode describing concomitant warm sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies in the eastern Pacific and cold SST anomalies in the central and western Pacific during its positive ‘warm’ phase1,2,3,4. Associated with basin-scale atmospheric, oceanographic and ecological changes2,4,5,6, the PDO index is a popular indicator in marine resource management7,8, with its historical sign reversals (for example, 1925, 1947 and 1977) heralded as regime shifts—climate-driven reconfigurations of species distributions and abundances with major socioeconomic impacts2,5,9,10,11,12,13,14,15.In 1977, an abrupt shift of the PDO into its positive phase triggered pronounced responses in salmon fisheries along the North American west coast: catches surged in the Gulf of Alaska (GOA) but declined in the northern California Current13,16,17. These synchronous changes, coinciding with shifts in SST and other physical and ecological variables, drew attention to the underlying pattern of low-frequency climate variability and ultimately led to the identification and formalization of the PDO2,3,9. Although initially defined in the context of its influence on northeastern Pacific salmon, the PDO index has since emerged as a significant correlate in population and community dynamics across trophic levels, including species ranging from phytoplankton to seabirds and marine mammals throughout the North Pacific18,19,20,21,22,23,24.In the past decade, previously quantified PDO–ecosystem relationships have been called into question25,26, prompting re-evaluations of the PDO’s regional impacts25,27,28,29 and claims that the mode itself fundamentally changed30. In the GOA, annual catches of salmon correlated negatively with the PDO from 2014–2019, a surprising departure from the significant positive correlation exhibited in previous decades2,13,27. Weakened responses to the PDO have been additionally documented among aggregated biological time series that include seabirds and ichthyoplankton in the California Current and groundfish, forage fish and crustaceans in the GOA29.In this Article, we show that although the PDO has not changed in pattern or strength, pan-basin warming now overwhelms its SST changes, producing periods during which regional SST anomalies diverge from what is expected of the PDO’s expression. We introduce the pan-basin pattern (PBP) as a new index describing this basin-wide warming, and discuss how interacting PDO and PBP variability can produce diverse biological responses, including those observed in GOA salmon catches. Updating understanding of these patterns of North Pacific climate and their respective impacts is critical to ensure appropriate use of environmental indices in management. Furthermore, this work emphasizes the role of interacting internal variability and anthropogenic warming to produce no-analogue ocean regimes including the persistent extreme warm conditions of the past decade.Emergent dominance of pan-basin warmingThe PDO is defined as the leading empirical orthogonal function (EOF) of SST anomalies in the North Pacific (20–65° N, 105–260° E), canonically following removal of the global mean SST (GMSST) signal2,3. By this construction, the PDO is designed to describe internal climate variability distinct from global-scale temperature changes. This canonical PDO variability has been stable through recent decades, as represented in the leading EOF of GMSST-removed SST anomalies among sliding retrospective 30-year windows (Fig. 1, right column). Similarly, second EOFs consistently resemble the SST footprint of the North Pacific Gyre Oscillation (NPGO)/Victoria Mode pattern31,32. Both patterns exhibit only minor deviations in spatial pattern and explain stable amounts of variance through time (EOF1: 20–26%; EOF2: 12–16%; Fig. 2, bottom row). Before 2014, removal of the GMSST signal before calculation of the leading EOFs is trivial—the PDO patterns represented by EOF1 calculated with and without removal of the GMSST are strongly correlated (R = 0.98–0.99; Extended Data Fig. 1 and Fig. 1) and differences in the explained variance are negligible (Fig. 2).Fig. 1: Leading patterns of North Pacific SST variability during sliding retrospective 30-year windows, shown for overlapping two-year time steps.In the left two columns, EOFs were calculated without removal of GMSST anomalies (that is, based on total SST anomalies). In the right two columns, EOFs were calculated following the removal of GMSST anomalies. The PBP is labelled in the EOF1 based on total SST anomalies for 1994–2023.Full size imageFig. 2: Percentage variance explained by EOFs calculated on the 30-year sliding windows.Top: EOFs for total SST anomalies. Bottom: EOFs for GMSST-removed SST anomalies. The red dashed lines indicate the approximate year of transition from the PDO to the PBP in EOF1 calculated from total SST anomalies. The modes associated with each EOF are labelled, as visually identified in Fig. 1.Full size imageWhen including years beyond 2013, we observe a departure from the historical norm; the PDO is replaced by a new basin-wide pattern in the leading EOF of the total SST anomalies (that is, GMSST not removed). By the 30-year period ending in 2017, the first EOF is unidirectional across the entire North Pacific basin, with all loadings of the same sign (Fig. 1). We refer to this pattern (that is, EOF1 of the total SST anomalies for 1994–2023) as the PBP. As the magnitude of the PBP supersedes that of the PDO, the percentage variance explained by EOF1 increases (21–51%) to exceed any historical 30-year interval of the PDO (Fig. 2). The transition from PDO dominance to PBP dominance is robust to the inclusion of only winter months (November to March; Extended Data Fig. 2) and to changes in the length of the sliding window on which the EOFs are calculated, occurring within the past decade when considering sliding windows of 20–100 years (Extended Data Figs. 3–5). The resulting PBP index (that is, principal component 1 of the total SST anomalies for 1994–2023) exhibits a linear correlation of 0.80 to GMSST time series (Extended Data Figs. 6 and 7).Robust PDO despite predominant warmingAlthough recently overshadowed by PBP warming, the PDO has neither changed in spatial pattern (Fig. 1) nor weakened relative to its historical expression (Fig. 2). For the 1994–2023 period, the SST pattern of the PDO occurs in the second EOF of total SST anomalies, tightly correlated with its representation in the first EOF of GMSST-removed SST anomalies (R = 0.99; Extended Data Fig. 1). Eigenvalues for this most recent (1994–2023) EOF1 of GMSST-removed SST anomalies and EOF2 of total SST anomalies are similar (0.12 versus 0.13) and within the historical range of GMSST-removed EOF1 values (0.095–0.170; Extended Data Fig. 8), and the resultant principal components are strongly correlated (Extended Data Figs. 6 and 7). However, the percentage variance of the PDO pattern in EOF2 of total SST anomalies decreases from 23 to 13% over the most recent decade, coincident with the overwhelming and increasing importance of the PBP in EOF1 (Fig. 2). Synchronous with the emergence of the PBP in EOF1, the PDO first appears in EOF2 of total SST anomalies in the 30-year period ending in 2015 (Fig. 1). The simultaneous change from the PBP to the first EOF and from the PDO to the second EOF underscores that these are two distinct patterns; the PDO emerges as both the leading mode of GMSST-removed SST anomalies and a secondary mode orthogonal to the PBP. Similarly, the historical EOF2 NPGO/Victoria Mode pattern is demoted to the third EOF of total SST anomalies for the 1994–2023 period, but explains a similar amount of absolute variance as in previous periods or with GMSST removed (Extended Data Fig. 9). These results indicate that although the dominant mode of total North Pacific SST change is now secular warming, the PDO and NPGO/Victoria Mode remain the leading internal climate modes.Revisiting North Pacific climate changesProjection of the most recent GMSST-removed EOF1 onto the full Extended Reconstructed Sea Surface Temperature (ERSST) dataset (1854–2024) reproduces the reversals of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) National Center for Environmental Information PDO index (https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/access/monitoring/pdo/; Fig. 3c and Extended Data Fig. 6), showing the negative cold regimes of 1890–1924 and 1947–1976 and positive warm regimes of 1925–1946 and 1977 to the late 1990s. Since 2000, sub-decadal reversals occurred around 2003, 2006, 2014 and 2020. Throughout the twentieth and twenty-first centuries, the PBP has increased along with the GMSST (Fig. 3a,b). The PDO probably plays some role in modulating global mean temperature, with previous negative PDO phases implicated in a hiatus in global mean surface temperature change through an increase in the heat content sequestered in the ocean subsurface in the tropics33,34,35,36. The apparent stepwise increase of the PBP coinciding with the transition into the positive PDO phase around 2014 could reflect such suppression and then rebound of the GMSST trend and/or the influence of reduced aerosol forcing in the western Pacific37.Fig. 3: Time series of basin-wide patterns and their regional expressions as predicted SST anomalies in LMEs of the eastern and western North Pacific.a, GMSST anomalies. b, Principal component (PC) time series for PBP, defined as the leading EOF of total SST anomalies for 1994–2023 projected onto the full ERSST record. c, PDO time series as reconstructed from the leading EOF of GMSST-removed SST anomalies for 1994–2023 projected onto the full ERSST record. d–g, Predicted SST anomaly signals associated with the PBP (yellow) and PDO (red and blue) compared with the total SST anomalies (solid black lines) and PBP + PDO SST anomalies (dashed black lines) in the GOA (d), California Current (CC; e), Oyashio Current (OC; f) and Kuroshio Current (KC; g) LMEs, all shown as the three-month rolling mean. h, Map of the locations of the four LMEs shown in d–g.Full size imagePDO-related SST anomalies are notably stronger in the eastern Pacific than in the western Pacific, whereas PBP-related anomalies are more uniform (Fig. 3d–g). Although we do not expect the SST anomalies associated with the two modes to perfectly sum to the total SST anomalies (Fig. 3d–g, solid versus dashed lines), the first two EOFs explain more than 60% of the total variance in the most recent 30 years and indeed capture much of the total variability. In the northeast Pacific’s California Current and GOA large marine ecosystems (LMEs) (Fig. 3h), historical SST anomalies before 2014 largely tracked the PDO component, consistent with strong PDO loading in these regions. Historical SST anomalies in the Kuroshio Current and Oyashio Current LMEs more closely follow the PBP anomalies, consistent with the relatively strong PBP loadings and weak PDO loadings across these regions.Crossplots of PDO- and PBP-related SST anomalies provide a framework for interpreting historical changes in the relative strength of regional expressions of global change (PBP) and internal variability (PDO) (Fig. 4a). Before 2014, variability in the northeast Pacific (GOA and California Current) concentrated along the PDO axis, consistent with the historical dominance of the PDO in these regions (Fig. 4b,c). From 2014–2016, strong PDO-positive and PBP-warming anomalies of comparable magnitude combined to produce exceptionally warm and persistent SST anomalies in the northeast Pacific, with notable marine heatwaves of 2014–2016 (the Blob) and 2019–2020 occurring when the PBP and PDO had constructive signals38,39,40,41,42,43. As the PDO became less positive from 2017–2020, PBP warming remained elevated; although the PBP signal dominated, positive SST anomalies in the eastern Pacific were still concordant with a positive PDO. However, when the PDO shifted into its negative phase around 2021, its associated northeast Pacific cooling was insufficient to offset the continued PBP warmth. Consequently, 2021–2024 represents the first sustained period of the recent historical record during which warming confounded PDO variability such that a negative ‘cold’ PDO phase did not coincide with negative SST anomalies in the eastern Pacific (Figs. 3d,e and 4b,c). In the western Pacific Kuroshio Current and Oyashio Current LMEs, where PDO loadings are historically weaker and more variable (Fig. 1), disagreement in the sign of the PDO and regional SST anomalies occurred around 2014–2019 during the previous negative PDO phase (Fig. 3f,g and Fig. 4d,e). In all four regions, the span of PDO SST anomaly variability is maintained while moving along the axis of global change, illustrating the superposition of internal variability on a shifting baseline.Fig. 4: Comparing regional impacts of internal PDO variability and global temperature change.a, Schematic for the interpretation of changes in SST related to internal variability (that is, the PDO; y axis) and global temperature change (that is, the PBP; x axis). In the top right and lower left quadrants PDO and PBP anomalies of the same direction yield constructive SST anomaly signals, whereas in the top left and lower right quadrants PDO and PBP anomalies of opposite signs are destructive. When the magnitude of the PDO-derived SST anomalies is greater than the absolute PBP-derived anomaly, internal variability dominates, whereas when the PBP SST is greater, global change overpowers the PDO. Years that fall within the hourglass are dominated by PDO variability, whereas years that fall within the bowtie are dominated by PBP change. b–d, As in a, predicted annual average SST anomalies in association with the PBP and PDO in LMEs of the North Pacific: GOA (b), CC (c), OC (d) and KC (e). Years are labelled for 2014–2023 only. The data point fill colours correspond to observed annual SST anomalies.Full size imageNon-stationary ecological responses to PDO variabilityAlthough numerous studies document strong historical correlations between North Pacific ecosystem components and the PDO2,5,13,18,19,20,21,22,23,24, observations suggest that some of these relationships have weakened or even reversed in recent years25,27,29. We revisit the seminal case study of salmon variability in the GOA to examine how the superposition of PDO variability and PBP warming can obscure ecosystem impacts2,13,16,17,44. From 1965–1988, annual catches of pink, sockeye and coho salmon (Oncorhynchus gorbuscha, O. nerka and O. kitsutch, respectively) showed strong positive correlations with the PDO index2,13,27. These correlations decayed from 1989–2013, then became significantly negative after 2014 (refs. 27,29), synchronous with the rising predominance of the PBP.We can hypothesize a cause for these changing correlations by building a simple conceptual model assuming that a theoretical biological response (for example, salmon abundance) can be described as a function of temperature with a normal distribution centred on the thermal optimum (Fig. 5)45,46. Because the magnitude of PDO-related SST anomalies remains consistent under PBP warming (Figs. 2 and 4), the absolute SST associated with a given PDO index value shifts with the warming baseline, moving along the response curve as secular warming progresses. Positive correlations between pre-1989 salmon catches in the GOA and the PDO index suggest that historical PDO-related SST variability spanned the ascending arm of the theoretical response curve (Fig. 5; scenario A). As PBP warming raises absolute SSTs associated with PDO variability, SSTs during positive PDO phases begin to exceed the thermal optimum, triggering negative biological responses and decorrelation with the PDO index during the 1989–2013 period (Fig. 5; scenario B). Once the PBP baseline exceeds the thermal optimum, PDO-related variability falls on the descending arm of the response curve, aligning with the shift to negative correlations after 2014 (Fig. 5; scenario C). This model may also explain the weakening of already negative PDO correlations; as PBP warming pushes PDO variability further down the descending arm of the response curve to where it flattens, the biological response to warming during positive PDO phases is reduced.Fig. 5: Conceptual model explaining changing PDO–biology relationships through time under long-term secular warming.This model assumes that a theoretical biological response (for example, salmon abundance) is described by a normal distribution as a function of SST, and that the range of SST anomalies variability associated with the PDO is maintained but shifted in absolute SST with PBP warming. In scenario A, the response positively correlates with the PDO index, as increasing PDO index values correspond to stronger biological responses, consistent with observed salmon catches in the GOA before 1989. In scenario B, with basin-wide warming, PDO variability shifts along the biological response curve towards the thermal optimum, resulting in decorrelation between the PDO index and biological response, as observed for GOA salmon catches from 1989–2013. In scenario C, as warming continues, PDO variability is shifted beyond the thermal optimum, resulting in negative correlations with the PDO index, as is seen for GOA salmon catches from 2014–2019. m is the slope of the linear correlation between PDO index values and the biological response. Salmon image from PhyloPic under a Creative Commons license PDM 1.0.Full size imageThe application of this conceptual model to different species and populations will produce different outcomes based on how the species-specific thermal optima align with regional expressions of PBP and PDO variability (for example, Figs. 3 and 4). For example, catches of salmon in the northern California Current (Washington, Oregon and California, near the species’ southern range) were historically negatively associated with the PDO index, albeit more weakly correlated with the PDO index than the GOA salmon catches2,13. Warmer SSTs in the south would place the salmon catches further along the response curve, which may explain the divergent historical responses to the PDO between the two regions. Critically, this conceptual model assumes that absolute SSTs primarily drive biological impacts. For biological responses to the PDO that are driven by variability associated with other aspects of the PDO, such as changes in upwelling or thermocline depth, the PDO–biology correlations may be unchanged or exhibit more complicated responses. Thus, this model offers a conceptual framework for understanding the diversity of biological responses to the PDO under PBP warming, including the weakening, strengthening, inversion or perpetuation of historical correlations. Further research is needed to explore whether incorporating both the PDO and PBP may recover some of the biological inferences lost since 2014.DiscussionWe demonstrate that the leading mode of interdecadal North Pacific SST changes recently transitioned from the PDO to a pattern of unidirectional change across the entire basin (that is, the PBP). For the first prolonged period of the recent observational record, a negative ‘cold’ PDO phase failed to coincide with cool SST anomalies in the eastern Pacific—a harbinger of the increasing non-stationarity in relationships between the PDO and regional SSTs (Fig. 3d,e). Despite explaining proportionally less variance, ongoing robust PDO variability indicates that drivers of the mode’s SST anomaly footprint have been resilient to warming through the early twenty-first century (Figs. 1 and 2). As the PDO is a statistically emergent pattern integrating several processes (for example, stochastic Aleutian Low forcing, teleconnections with the tropics, and ocean Rossby waves)4,47, its future evolutio

items.title: Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation slowdown suppresses Atlantic Niño variability
items.body: IntroductionThe Atlantic Niño is the primary mode of variability in the tropical Atlantic Ocean1,2,3, significantly affecting not only tropical rainfall, including the Sahel and Amazon basins precipitation4,5, but also remote extratropical regions6 and tropical inter-basin processes7,8,9,10. Atlantic Niño events result from anomalous exchange of heat and momentum between the ocean and the overlying atmosphere. Positive sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies in the central and eastern equatorial Atlantic alter the sea level pressure and weaken the easterly trade winds. Anomalous winds perturb the thermocline below, generating downwelling oceanic Kelvin waves that travel eastward along the Equator and deepen the eastern equatorial thermocline. A deepened thermocline increases the heat content within the mixed layer, further enhancing the initial positive SST anomalies1,2,3.Recent studies have identified a significant persistent decrease in the Atlantic Niño variability since the 1970’s11,12,13, and this variability is projected to further weaken under global warming14. The Atlantic Niño decline has been mostly attributed to a decoupling between surface and subsurface temperature variations due to a persistent deeper thermocline11,12,14, but also with contributions from weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling15 and basin-wide warming related to climate change12,13. Weakened air-sea coupling in the equatorial Atlantic is caused by weaker and more stable winds that reduce the effectiveness of wind anomalies in promoting changes in the thermocline15. Rising SSTs due to enhanced CO2 concentrations in the atmosphere increase the heat flux from the ocean to the atmosphere, thus damping the initial positive SST anomalies13.Although changes in Atlantic Niño feedbacks can be directly affected by global warming, these could also be driven or amplified by teleconnection processes16,17. The equatorial Atlantic can be influenced by the variability of the Pacific and Indian Oceans on inter-annual to decadal timescales through tropical inter-basin interactions. First, El Niño events, characterized by positive SST anomalies in the central-eastern Pacific, displace the Atlantic Walker cell eastwards, resulting in weaker trade winds over the Atlantic basin18. As such, persistent enhanced El Niño Southern Oscillation (ENSO) activity can possibly lead to weaker Atlantic Niño variability. Secondly, warm anomalies in the tropical Indian Ocean intensify the Atlantic equatorial winds through a tropical baroclinic response19, thus possibly favouring enhanced Atlantic Niño variability. However, the recent period of reduced ENSO activity20,21 and the CO2-driven Indian Ocean warming are inconsistent with a decreased Atlantic Niño variability through tropical basin interaction mechanisms. Lastly, the intensity of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), which is the major circulation system in the Atlantic Ocean, has been shown to affect SST variability in the Indian22 and Pacific23 Oceans. In the Atlantic Ocean, a weakening of the AMOC leads to significant warming in the Tropical South Atlantic due to a deepening of the thermocline24,25. The AMOC weakening also decreases the southeastern trade winds over the Atlantic basin17, which could impact the Atlantic Niño variability. Despite being an ongoing topic of research, there is increasing proxy-data and observational evidence suggesting that the AMOC has weakened since the mid-20th century25,26,27, possibly consistent with reduced Atlantic Niño activity since the 1970’s. However, the response of equatorial SST variability to AMOC changes is yet to be elucidated. In this context, we first perform idealized subpolar North Atlantic freshwater hosing experiments with an Earth System Model to investigate AMOC-driven teleconnection processes that could reduce the Atlantic Niño variability. We then use our results to evaluate the sensitivity of the Atlantic Niño variability to an AMOC weakening under global warming.ResultsAtlantic Niño response to an AMOC weakeningTo investigate the impact of an AMOC weakening on Atlantic Niño variability and dynamics, we perform numerical simulations with the Australian Community Climate and Earth System Simulator version 1.5 (ACCESS-ESM1.5)25,28. The ACCESS-ESM1.5 model is skilful in simulating both AMOC intensity and Equatorial Atlantic mean state and feedbacks, which allows a realistic assessment of the linkage between the two phenomena. Firstly, the model simulates the AMOC at a strength of 19 Sv (Fig. 1a) in the pre-industrial scenario, in agreement with direct AMOC estimates of the mid-twentieth century (20.1 Sv from ref. 29). Furthermore, the model captures the observed equatorial Atlantic mean state during the peak season of the Atlantic Niño (June-July-August (JJA)), including the negative zonal SST gradient and thermocline slope (Fig. 2d)15. Lastly, the ACCESS-ESM1.5 simulates the relationship between coupled processes in the equatorial Atlantic in the pre-industrial climate (Fig. 2a–c), important for Atlantic Niño development and known as Bjerkenes Feedbacks, with correlation coefficients greater than 0.7 (Supplementary Table S1), and simulating feedback strengths in close agreement with observations (Fig. 2a–c)14,30.Fig. 1: Structural and variability changes in Atlantic Niño due to an AMOC collapse.a Temporal evolution of the AMOC strength, defined as the annual-mean maximum Atlantic Ocean meridional streamfunction (Sv) at 26∘N in the AMOC-on and AMOC-off experiments. b Atlantic Niño index, defined as sea surface temperature anomalies (SSTa) in the eastern equatorial Atlantic (ATL3 region; 3∘S-3∘N, 20∘W-0∘) in June-July-August. Shading indicates the long-term (second-degree polynomial) variability trend (21-years running standard deviation) of the Atlantic Niño index. c, d Atlantic Niño index regressed onto SSTa in AMOC-on and AMOC-off, respectively e, f Atlantic Niño impact over precipitation, wind, and sea-level pressure fields in AMOC-on (d) and AMOC-off experiments (e). This idealized forcing was implemented to provide a robust assessment of the impact of AMOC strength on the global climate. Given the high internal variability of the equatorial Atlantic, this forcing provides a high signal-to-noise ratio. In this water hosing simulation, the AMOC takes approximately 170 years to decline from an intensity of 19 Sv to below 5 Sv (Fig. 1a). This period of rapid weakening is followed by a slower reduction, ultimately ending up in a new equilibrium state, when the AMOC strength stabilizes at around 3 Sv (hereafter referred to as AMOC-off; red line in Fig. 1a). This simulation is compared to the pre-industrial control run31 (hereafter referred as AMOC-on).The collapse of the AMOC significantly reduces the northward Atlantic Ocean heat transport, leading to accumulation of heat in the Southern Hemisphere and a deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, thereby reversing the inter-hemispheric temperature contrast (Supplementary Fig. 1). In response to this, the atmospheric circulation in the Northern Hemisphere intensifies in an attempt to export the excess energy out of the Southern Hemisphere. In the equatorial Atlantic, these global changes drive a southward shift of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ) and a weakening the equatorial southeasterly trade winds (Supplementary Fig. 1).The freshwater hosing induces a gradual weakening (Fig. 1b and Supplementary Fig. 2) of the Atlantic Niño, with a 21% weakening between years 50 and 100, and ultimately reaching a 37% weakening between years 400 and 500 (Supplementary Fig. 2) compared to the unperturbed state (AMOC-on). This weakening is accompanied by a significant change in the spatial pattern of the Atlantic Niño SST anomalies (Fig. 1c, d). Under a collapsed AMOC, the warming core shrinks towards the central equatorial Atlantic, with cooling observed in the southeastern Atlantic (Fig. 1d). The new spatial pattern results in substantially different wind and precipitation responses (Fig. 1e, f). The classic positive Atlantic Niño fingerprint causes negative sea-level pressure anomalies in the eastern equatorial Atlantic, weakening the southeasterly winds and shifting the ITCZ southward. This results in increased precipitation along the equator, including the Amazon and Congo basins (Fig. 1e). On the other hand, the anomalous surface pattern under a collapsed AMOC drives higher sea level pressure in the southeastern South Atlantic (Fig. 1f), strengthening the southeasterlies. This leads to drier conditions in south equatorial and tropical western Africa, while increasing precipitation in northeastern Brazil. The new pattern shows a diminished impact of the Atlantic Niño on eastern Amazon rainfall. It is important noting that the tropical Atlantic is one of the remote regions most strongly impacted by an AMOC collapse. As such, large changes in the mean state under this scenario (Supplementary Fig. 1) can possibly alter the ocean-atmosphere feedbacks at play in the equatorial Atlantic mode, as we discuss in the following section.Weakened ocean-atmosphere coupling due to an AMOC collapseTo investigate the mechanisms behind changes in the variability of the Atlantic Niño when the AMOC weakens and collapses, we evaluate the three main ocean-atmosphere coupling feedbacks (Bjerknes Feedbacks), related to the development of Atlantic Niño events30. First, the zonal advection feedback (BF1) measures the amplification of the response of eastern equatorial SST anomalies to anomalous zonal wind stress in the western equatorial Atlantic. Secondly, the thermocline feedback (BF2) identifies the intensity of the response of the thermocline slope due to changes in zonal wind stress. Finally, the upwelling feedback (BF3) measures the effect of local changes in the eastern Atlantic thermocline depth on SST anomalies (Methods).To understand how the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic are changing due to the weakening of the AMOC, we split the North Atlantic hosing experiment into 4 periods: before the addition of freshwater (P0; AMOC-on; blue in Fig. 2); between 50 and 150 years after the addition of freshwater (P1; green); between 150 and 250 years after the addition of freshwater (P2; yellow); and during the AMOC-off period (P3; red). Results indicate that its weakening during the transient AMOC slow-down (P1 and P2) is mostly driven by a weakened upwelling feedback (BF3), and with significant contribution from the zonal advective feedback (BF1). During P1 and P2, BF3 weakens by approximately 60% and 120%, respectively (Fig. 2c), while the zonal advective feedback (BF1) weakens by 40% and 92%, respectively (Fig. 2a). On the other hand, the thermocline feedback (BF2; Fig. 2b) increases by up to 20% during P1 and P2. Finally, under a collapsed AMOC (P3), the reduced Atlantic Niño variability is primarily caused by the reduction in the upwelling feedback (BF3), followed by the zonal advective feedback (BF1). The thermocline feedback (BF2) reduces by only 30%, indicating that the reduced variability is primarily driven by BF1 and BF3.In understanding how an AMOC weakening can affect the Bjerknes feedbacks in the equatorial Atlantic, we initially evaluate the temporal evolution of the main features of the coupled tropical climate. First, trends in mixed-layer temperatures (Fig. 2d) indicate a more pronounced warming in the subsurface layer of the eastern equatorial Atlantic, resulting in a deeper thermocline (Fig. 2f) and consequently a weaker influence on surface waters (e.g., weakened BF3). Furthermore, the western equatorial Atlantic experiences a subsurface cooling trend, resulting in a shallower thermocline. Together, these changes reverse the thermocline slope as the AMOC collapses (Fig. 2e).Here, we identify two teleconnection processes from the subarctic North Atlantic that contribute to reversing the equatorial thermocline slope. First, an atmospheric teleconnection is triggered by reduced northward oceanic heat transport (OHT). To compensate for the heat deficit in the Northern Hemisphere, the atmospheric circulation intensifies and expands southwards to export heat from the Southern Hemisphere32,33 (Supplementary Fig. 1). This process is also identified in our simulations by strengthened atmospheric subtropical circulation in the North Atlantic (Fig. 2g) and a southward shift of the ITCZ (Supplementary Fig. 3a). This meridional atmospheric teleconnection drives the weakening of the equatorial winds (Fig. 2h and Supplementary Fig. 3b,c), which ultimately act on decreasing the thermocline slope.Secondly, an oceanic teleconnection is triggered by displaced isopycnals in the subarctic region, due to freshwater input and reduced deep ocean convection. Downwelling Kelvin waves propagate along the western boundary and reach the equatorial Atlantic25,34,35,36. In the ACCESS-ESM1.5 model, we assess the propagation of coastal Kelvin waves through their impact on the baroclinicity of the mean flow in the western boundary currents of the North Atlantic - namely, the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current (see Methods, Supplementary Fig. 4). As baroclinic Kelvin waves propagate due to an increased density gradient towards the boundary, the offshore large-scale wind-driven pressure gradient weakens. Thus weakening the boundary currents through the thermal-wind balance34,37,38,39,40. An analysis of the western boundary currents reveals that Kelvin wave propagation reduces the zonal density gradients in both the Gulf Stream and the North Brazil Current, consistent with the expected response from thermal wind balance (Supplementary Fig. 4; Methods). Noting that in addition to being affected by Kelvin waves25 under an AMOC weakening scenario, the intensity of the boundary currents can also be affected by freshwater advection through interior pathways41.In the equatorial Atlantic, Kelvin waves also contribute to the initial deepening of the mean equatorial thermocline. The suppressed eastern upwelling leads to intense rates of warming in the eastern equatorial Atlantic. This reinforces the reduced surface east-west SST gradient and, consequently, weakening of the trade winds, thus triggering the reversal of the thermocline slope. The deepening of the eastern equatorial thermocline suppresses the upwelling feedback (BF3) under AMOC weakening. It is important to note that while Kelvin waves play a significant role in reducing the zonal SST gradient along the equator, it is the interaction with atmospheric processes that ultimately shapes the final thermocline structure.As a result of these teleconnections mechanisms, when the AMOC collapses, there is a reversal in the direction of the trade winds (Fig. 2h), in the thermocline slope (Fig. 2e), and in the zonal SST gradient (Supplementary Fig. 1a). These changes result in increased heat content in the eastern Atlantic mixed-layer (Fig. 2d). Under this new configuration of the equatorial Atlantic, Atlantic Niños are likely triggered from the east (Fig. 1f), where heat anomalies propagate from east-to-west. In this scenario, easterly wind anomalies in the eastern Atlantic reactivate the upwelling on the African coast, displacing the eastern warm waters toward the central Atlantic, as indicated by a reversed relationship between eastern upwelling and ATL3 SSTs (BF3 red line in Fig. 2c). This mechanism is also consistent with the reversal of BF1 (red line in Fig. 2a), where positive SST anomalies in ATL3 are now related to easterly wind anomalies, further contributing to the advection of positive SST anomalies from east to west. These results indicate that the more centred equatorial Atlantic mode driven by an AMOC shutdown operates through substantially different ocean-atmosphere feedbacks. The absence of a positive upwelling feedback when the AMOC collapses suggests that the more centred pattern could be associated with reduced amplitude.Changes in atmospheric meridional heat transport also affect the mean state and variability of the tropical Pacific and Indian oceans that can in turn affect the Atlantic Ocean16. To investigate the possible role of the Pacific ocean in the Atlantic Niño weakening, we evaluate changes in the intensity of the equatorial trade winds and ENSO amplitude, as persistent increased ENSO activity can lead to weaker Atlantic trades, thus reducing Atlantic Niño activity15. We find that the Pacific trades (160∘E-90∘W; 5∘S-5∘N) intensify by 17% and ENSO weakens by 18% (Niño34 standard deviation change) in the AMOC-off period. Both changes are consistent with a Pacific mean state change towards a more La Niña-like state42. As multi-year La Niña events tend to trigger Atlantic Niño events43, changes in the Pacific Ocean do not contribute to the weakened Atlantic Niño. The tropical Indian Ocean (50∘E-90∘E; 5∘S-5∘N) has a small, not significant, annual mean cooling response (-0.23∘C) in our AMOC-off experiment, thus likely playing a minor role in equatorial Atlantic changes16.Impacts of a weakened AMOC in historical and future scenariosSimilarly to the results of the idealized AMOC weakening experiments presented above, the upwelling feedback (BF3) has been shown to be the major contributor to the decreased Atlantic Niño variability seen since the 1970’s11,12,44. Furthermore, based on SST and Sea Surface Salinity (SSS) trends in the Atlantic, the AMOC has been suggested to be weakening since the mid-20th century25,45,46,47.
